<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_seek_:
```c
static int lfs_dir_seek_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir, lfs_off_t off) {
    // simply walk from head dir
    int err = lfs_dir_rewind_(lfs, dir);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // first two for ./..
    dir->pos = lfs_min(2, off);
    off -= dir->pos;

    // skip superblock entry
    dir->id = (off > 0 && lfs_pair_cmp(dir->head, lfs->root) == 0);

    while (off > 0) {
        if (dir->id == dir->m.count) {
            if (!dir->m.split) {
                return LFS_ERR_INVAL;
            }

            err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, dir->m.tail);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }

            dir->id = 0;
        }

        int diff = lfs_min(dir->m.count - dir->id, off);
        dir->id += diff;
        dir->pos += diff;
        off -= diff;
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: I did not flag any other fragments because everything else in this function uses standard C language constructs (static function, pointer dereferences, function calls, logical operators, while loop, block-scope declaration of 'int diff' which is valid in C99 and later, // comments which are standard since C99, etc.) and does not by itself show any compiler-specific language extension. The only constructs that could hide compiler-specific extensions are calls to lfs_min, since that identifier is likely a macro or inline function defined elsewhere; some implementations of min-like macros use compiler extensions (e.g. GCC statement-expressions ({ ... }) or typeof). Because the definition of lfs_min is not in this snippet, I flagged its call sites for investigation. No other lines in the shown code exhibit evidence of compiler-specific extensions.
